articles.headline: U.S. Pushes Agencies to Free Up Spectrum
articles.snippet: The government said it would invest $40 million in the next year and $60 million more over the next five years to find ways to share lightly used airwaves.
articles.abstract: The government said it would invest $40 million in the next year and $60 million more over the next five years to find ways to share lightly used airwaves.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years after President Obama laid out an ambitious plan to double the country’s supply of airwaves for use in high-speed wireless Internet service, the White House on Friday announced efforts intended in part to spur participation by government agencies that have been slow to join the cause.

articles.headline:
Coal Industry Pins
Hopes on Exports as
U.S. Market Shrinks
articles.snippet: Environmental worries complicate an energy company’s plan to mine an Indian tribe’s large deposit of coal and ship it to Asia.
articles.abstract: Environmental worries complicate an energy company’s plan to mine an Indian tribe’s large deposit of coal and ship it to Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: CROW AGENCY, Mont. — Every few hours trains packed with coal pass through the sagebrush-covered landscape here in southern Montana, some on their way north to Canadian ports for shipment to Japan and South Korea. If the mining company Cloud Peak Energy has its way, many more trains will cross the prairie to far larger proposed export terminals in Washington State.

articles.headline: Talk of Takeover Grows at Health Management Hospital Group
articles.snippet: The chief executive of Health Management Associates is planning to depart, and speculation about a possible sale has sent the company’s stock higher.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of Health Management Associates is planning to depart, and speculation about a possible sale has sent the company’s stock higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the chief executive of Health Management Associates, the for-profit hospital system, abruptly announced nearly three weeks ago that he would be leaving to lead a religious mission in South America, speculation has mounted about whether the company could be headed for a takeover.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: How to Avoid an Estate Battle After You Die
articles.snippet: Battles over two wills signed by Huguette Clark, the heiress to a copper fortune who died in 2011 at 104, offer lessons even for people who don’t have $300 million estates.
articles.abstract: Battles over two wills signed by Huguette Clark, the heiress to a copper fortune who died in 2011 at 104, offer lessons even for people who don’t have $300 million estates.
articles.lead_paragraph: It might seem that a woman who died at 104 after spending 20 years in a hospital despite being healthy enough to live in one of her three stately homes, accumulated a vast collection of dolls and preferred to communicate in French even though her father had been a United States senator would have little to teach the rest of us.

articles.headline: The Unspoken Stigma of Workplace Flexibility
articles.snippet: Women who take advantage of flexible work schedules may be viewed as not committed to work, but men may be penalized even more.
articles.abstract: Women who take advantage of flexible work schedules may be viewed as not committed to work, but men may be penalized even more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Assume for a moment that your employer let you decide when and where you worked — you might arrive early so you could leave in time to care for a child, or work part of the week from home. Or perhaps you want to reduce your hours for a while to care for an aging parent. How would you be perceived if you raised your hand for one of these options?

articles.headline: Player in Leaks Case, Out From Behind Camera
articles.snippet: The documentarian Laura Poitras says her role in the leaking of American surveillance programs was “not something I was seeking out.”
articles.abstract: The documentarian Laura Poitras says her role in the leaking of American surveillance programs was “not something I was seeking out.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Alex Gibney recalled bumping into his fellow documentarian Laura Poitras at the airport last year, when they both happened to be taking the New York-to-London flight.

articles.headline:
Heavy Pressure
Led to Decision
by Obama on
Syrian Arms
articles.snippet: When President Obama agreed to send small arms and ammunition to Syrian rebels, he had to be almost dragged into the decision by advisers, critics and even Bill Clinton.
articles.abstract: When President Obama agreed to send small arms and ammunition to Syrian rebels, he had to be almost dragged into the decision by advisers, critics and even Bill Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For two years, President Obama has resisted being drawn deeper into the civil war in Syria. It was a miserable problem, he told aides, and not one he thought he could solve. At most, it could be managed. And besides, he wanted to be remembered for getting out of Middle East wars, not embarking on new ones.

articles.headline: Iran Moderate Wins Presidency by a Large Margin
articles.snippet: Hassan Rowhani, who advocates greater personal freedoms and a more conciliatory approach to the world, avoided a runoff in the election to replace Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
articles.abstract: Hassan Rowhani, who advocates greater personal freedoms and a more conciliatory approach to the world, avoided a runoff in the election to replace Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — In a striking repudiation of the ultraconservatives who wield power in Iran, voters here overwhelmingly elected a mild-mannered cleric who advocates greater personal freedoms and a more conciliatory approach to the world.

articles.headline: In Countrywide Case, Watchdogs Without Any Bark
articles.snippet: The mortgage-pool case now in a New York court is putting trustee banks under the microscope.
articles.abstract: The mortgage-pool case now in a New York court is putting trustee banks under the microscope.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR the last two weeks, a justice in New York State Supreme Court has heard testimony in one of the most pivotal cases of the financial crisis. The hearings will tell whether Bank of America can extinguish legal liability for more than a million Countrywide Financial loans by paying $8.5 billion in cash and agreeing to loan servicing improvements in a settlement struck with 22 investors in 2011.

articles.headline: In Utah, a Local Hero Accused
articles.snippet: A wealthy Web marketer was known for acts of generosity. But the government, which has charged him with defrauding customers, sees him in a different light.
articles.abstract: A wealthy Web marketer was known for acts of generosity. But the government, which has charged him with defrauding customers, sees him in a different light.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE morning after a catastrophic earthquake leveled buildings and killed thousands of people in Haiti in 2010, an Internet marketing millionaire from St. George, Utah, named Jeremy Johnson decided to cancel all his business meetings and arrange his own ad hoc aid mission.

articles.headline: China’s Great Uprooting: Moving 250 Million Into Cities
articles.snippet: A 12-year plan to move hundreds of millions of rural residents into cities is intended to spur economic growth, but could have unintended consequences, skeptics warn.
articles.abstract: A 12-year plan to move hundreds of millions of rural residents into cities is intended to spur economic growth, but could have unintended consequences, skeptics warn.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China is pushing ahead with a sweeping plan to move 250 million rural residents into newly constructed towns and cities over the next dozen years — a transformative event that could set off a new wave of growth or saddle the country with problems for generations to come.

articles.headline: Tea for 2? Kentucky Senators in a Marriage of Convenience
articles.snippet: Senators Mitch McConnell and Rand Paul, both Republicans, have formed an odd-couple, scratch-my-back alliance that stretches from Washington to Louisville.
articles.abstract: Senators Mitch McConnell and Rand Paul, both Republicans, have formed an odd-couple, scratch-my-back alliance that stretches from Washington to Louisville.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Their relationship got off on an awful footing. In a Republican primary in his home state of Kentucky, Senator Mitch McConnell backed the establishment candidate in 2010, blinkered to the historic Tea Party wave that swept in the political newcomer Rand Paul.

articles.headline: Borghese v. Borghese: Battle for a Royal Name
articles.snippet: The issue over who may use the Borghese history, at least for marketing purposes, is at the center of one of the most contentious lawsuits facing trial in New York courts this summer.
articles.abstract: The issue over who may use the Borghese history, at least for marketing purposes, is at the center of one of the most contentious lawsuits facing trial in New York courts this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not just anyone can lay claim to the name Borghese, carried by the Italian noble family that has included rulers, philosophers and even a pope. Perhaps not even the Borgheses themselves.

articles.headline:
Even Pessimists Feel
Optimistic About the
American Economy
articles.snippet: In a shift, many economists in academia and on Wall Street see a brighter outlook right around the corner, not just far into the future.
articles.abstract: In a shift, many economists in academia and on Wall Street see a brighter outlook right around the corner, not just far into the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, the economy has failed to grow the way it once did. Unemployment has not stayed this high, this long, since the 1930s.

articles.headline: After Profits, Defense Contractor Faces the Pitfalls of Cybersecurity
articles.snippet: Mike McConnell, who once led the National Security Agency, is now the chief architect of Booz Allen’s cyberstrategy — and among the executives facing tough questions after a data leak.
articles.abstract: Mike McConnell, who once led the National Security Agency, is now the chief architect of Booz Allen’s cyberstrategy — and among the executives facing tough questions after a data leak.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the United Arab Emirates wanted to create its own version of the National Security Agency, it turned to Booz Allen Hamilton to replicate the world’s largest and most powerful spy agency in the sands of Abu Dhabi.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Disruptions: Mobile Competition Shifts to Software Design
articles.snippet: From the outside, most smartphones look the same, and technology companies seem to be making a bigger effort to distinguish themselves by the interface experience.
articles.abstract: From the outside, most smartphones look the same, and technology companies seem to be making a bigger effort to distinguish themselves by the interface experience.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last week, Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, stood on stage at the company’s Worldwide Developers Conference without a new version of the iPhone or the iPad or some new device.

articles.headline:
Turkey Expands
Violent Reaction to
Street Unrest
articles.snippet: Turkish authorities took aim not just at the demonstrators in Taksim Square, but also at the medics who treated their injuries and the business owners who sheltered them.
articles.abstract: Turkish authorities took aim not just at the demonstrators in Taksim Square, but also at the medics who treated their injuries and the business owners who sheltered them.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish authorities widened their crackdown on the antigovernment protest movement on Sunday, taking aim not just at the demonstrators themselves, but also at the medics who treat their injuries, the business owners who shelter them and the foreign news media flocking here to cover a growing political crisis threatening to paralyze the government of Prıme Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, Sebnem Arsu and Ceylan Yeginsu

articles.headline: Lines Blur in U.S.-Europe Debate on Austerity
articles.snippet: A long-running economic policy debate over austerity versus stimulus was expected to be muted at the Group of 8 summit as participants concentrated on addressing the escalating civil war in Syria.
articles.abstract: A long-running economic policy debate over austerity versus stimulus was expected to be muted at the Group of 8 summit as participants concentrated on addressing the escalating civil war in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Obama begins an annual meeting with the leaders of some of the world’s richest nations on Monday in Northern Ireland, the economic-policy gulf that has divided them since the global crash in 2008 has narrowed significantly — just not exactly in ways that the White House would have liked.

articles.headline: Future of 3-D TV Murky as ESPN Ends Channel
articles.snippet: ESPN’s move spurred a debate about whether anyone would be left watching in 3-D television soon, and whether anything would be available worth watching.
articles.abstract: ESPN’s move spurred a debate about whether anyone would be left watching in 3-D television soon, and whether anything would be available worth watching.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, 3-D was hailed as the next big thing in television, the logical successor to high definition. But viewers in the United States did not buy the hype, and now the eye-popping format is seen as an expensive flop.

articles.headline: Choice of Health Plans to Vary Sharply From State to State
articles.snippet: Some states have attracted an array of insurers for their exchanges, while options in other states may be limited.
articles.abstract: Some states have attracted an array of insurers for their exchanges, while options in other states may be limited.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a typical 40-year-old uninsured woman in Maine goes to the new state exchange to buy health insurance this fall, she may have just two companies to choose from: the one that already sells most individual policies in the state, and a complete unknown — a nonprofit start-up.

articles.headline: Faltering Economy in China Dims Job Prospects for Graduates
articles.snippet: Graduating seniors say that few are finding jobs, and that some offers extended over the winter are being rescinded, as the Chinese economy falters.
articles.abstract: Graduating seniors say that few are finding jobs, and that some offers extended over the winter are being rescinded, as the Chinese economy falters.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A record seven million students will graduate from universities and colleges across China in the coming weeks, but their job prospects appear bleak — the latest sign of a troubled Chinese economy.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Sue-Lin Wong

articles.headline: Big News Forges Its Own Path
articles.snippet: Major news stories increasingly find their own digital path, and no one feels the need to work with the traditional power players to make it happen.
articles.abstract: Major news stories increasingly find their own digital path, and no one feels the need to work with the traditional power players to make it happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a visit to Toronto last week, I noticed the entire city was pivoting around a story by Gawker, a site that has a broad range of interests, but at its core is dedicated to detailing the running silliness of life in Manhattan.

articles.headline: As U.S. Plugs Border in Arizona, Crossings Shift to South Texas
articles.snippet: A shift in the front line of the battle against illegal crossings has intensified debate over an immigration overhaul; some say a Texas influx shows the need to prioritize border security.
articles.abstract: A shift in the front line of the battle against illegal crossings has intensified debate over an immigration overhaul; some say a Texas influx shows the need to prioritize border security.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A surge in migrant traffic across the Southwest border into Texas has resulted in a milestone: the front line of the battle against illegal crossings from Mexico has shifted for the first time in over a decade away from Arizona to the Rio Grande Valley of South Texas.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Julia Preston

articles.headline: Under Pressure, Stewart Shifts Company’s Focus
articles.snippet: After posting a loss in the first quarter, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia redesigned its print and digital offerings in hopes of returning to profitability.
articles.abstract: After posting a loss in the first quarter, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia redesigned its print and digital offerings in hopes of returning to profitability.
articles.lead_paragraph: To follow Martha Stewart, even briefly, is a test of endurance. On a recent afternoon, Ms. Stewart wrapped up posing for a photo shoot for Martha Stewart Halloween magazine at her company’s Manhattan headquarters, as makeup artists briskly wiped glitter off her cheeks and disassembled her fairy-godmother bouffant. She hopped off her makeup chair and sprinted into the neighboring studio to check on a Martha Stewart Weddings cover photo shoot featuring $50 million worth of engagement rings.

articles.headline: From Inner Circle of Iran, a Pragmatic Victor
articles.snippet: Analysts say a priority of Iran’s president-elect, Hassan Rowhani, will be mediating the strained relationship between the citizens and the conservative leadership.
articles.abstract: Analysts say a priority of Iran’s president-elect, Hassan Rowhani, will be mediating the strained relationship between the citizens and the conservative leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — As Iranians responded to the victory of the cleric Hassan Rowhani in the country’s presidential race over the weekend by erupting into street parties not seen in many years, it almost seemed as if some sort of reformist revolution could be under way.

articles.headline: Justices Block Law Requiring Voters to Prove Citizenship
articles.snippet: In a 7-to-2 ruling Monday, the Supreme Court said an Arizona law requiring prospective voters to give proof of their citizenship was displaced by legislation at the federal level.
articles.abstract: In a 7-to-2 ruling Monday, the Supreme Court said an Arizona law requiring prospective voters to give proof of their citizenship was displaced by legislation at the federal level.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday in a 7-to-2 decision that Arizona may not require documentary proof of citizenship from people seeking to vote in federal elections there.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Lets Regulators Sue Over Generic Drug Deals
articles.snippet: The justices ruled on Monday that brand-name drug makers could face antitrust charges for paying generic competitors to keep cheaper copies of a drug off the market.
articles.abstract: The justices ruled on Monday that brand-name drug makers could face antitrust charges for paying generic competitors to keep cheaper copies of a drug off the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pharmaceutical companies that pay rivals to keep less-expensive generic versions of best-selling drugs off the market can expect greater federal scrutiny after a Supreme Court ruling on Monday.
